Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Designer Plasmonic Materials as Tunable Sensing and Spectroscopy Platforms
Award.AbstractNarration: The Analytical and Surface Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry will support the CAREER development plan of Prof. Jennifer Shumaker-Parry of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Utah. Prof. Shumaker-Parry and her students will develop and study unique plasmonic architectures with optical properties that may be tailored through organized assembly and controlled fabrication methods. Fundamental studies of the correlation of optical properties with structure shape and assembly will form a basis for tailoring and optimizing these plasmonic systems as enhanced platforms for sensing and spectroscopy applications. The research will provide multidisciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students. Prof. Shumaker-Parry also will integrate research in nanomaterials and spectroscopy with educational activities focused on development of a week-long module for a summer scholars program for in-coming freshman women interested in math and science careers and a mentoring program for local middle school Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement (MESA) clubs to encourage minority and female students to continue on a STEM-based track into high school and in their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Career Award supported research focused on tailoring the physical properties of metal nanostructures to control the optical properties. The research led to design guidelines for controlling the spectral range of the plasmonic response of metal nanostructures. At specific frequencies, a resonance of oscillating surface electrons is produced leading to plasmons and large enhancements in light absorption and scattering at visible and infrared wavelengths. Graduate and undergraduate students developed new methodologies for combining synthesis with fabrication to create new nanostructured substrates. Through detailed spectroscopic analysis, the surface chemistry of citrate-capped nanoparticles was studied. Because surface chemistry drives particle stability and is essential for controlling behavior in applications, studies of the citrate at gold nanoparticles has implications for a broad range of applications of these nanomaterials. The research on tailoring the optical properties of plasmonic antennas has implications for the very broad range of applications relying on light-matter interactions, including biological and chemical sensing, new platforms for solar energy conversion, plasmon-driven chemistry for photocatalysis, and medical applications in nanomedicine for drug delivery and localized phototherapeutics. Through the studies, graduate students and undergraduate students gained expertise in synthesis, fabrication methods, materials characterization, surface analysis and spectroscopy studies. In most cases, students worked in teams and learned to collaborate with scientists and engineers both on campus and at other institutions. Senior undergraduates and graduate students served as mentors, gaining leadership experiences and building a more solid knowledge base through teaching mentees about the science being investigated and the methods used for the studies. Graduate and undergraduate students learned to communicate research findings through manuscript preparation and poster and oral presentations at local, national, and international conferences. Educational activities were developed for multiple groups, including female undergraduate students in the College of Science ACCESS Program at the University of Utah, MESA Clubs in the Salt Lake City School District, and elementary student groups. A week-long set of activities was developed and implemented in a summer program that is part of the ACCESS experience for in-coming freshman women with the purpose of providing the women with an interdisciplinary experience. Multiple hands-on research events were carried out through a partnership with MESA Clubs at the Salt Lake City Center for Science Education, a local magnet school. Students learned to synthesize nanoparticles, investigated light-matter interactions through home-build spectroscope boxes, and visited campus to use electron microscopes and tour the Nanofabrication facilities. A special tiered mentoring activity involved graduate students advising MESA Club junior and high school students in developing a lesson on light-matter interactions and helping to implement the lesson in a local 6th grade classroom. Hands on polymer and nanoparticle syntheses were carried out with different groups of elementary students, both on campus and in the school classroom. Through these activities, students were exposed to the many facets of chemistry, from synthesis to physical chemistry related to light-matter interactions, and disseminated the research to the local public through presentations.
